results.title: Le Quebec as seen by Cartier-Bresson
results.brief_description: The photographs of Henri Cartier-Bresson were the first ever to be displayed in the Louvre, Paris. In this film the world famous photographer turns his lens on the Quebec scene, finding there the same fascination with form and movement that gives his work a mark of individuality. Here, in town and country, are young people, old people, streets and fences, homes and edifices captured in a moment of time to give a composite representation of the world of Quebec.

results.title: Le Quatrieme Pouvoir
results.brief_description:
Yves Dorget, a newspaper reporter and Catherine Carre, a TV anchorwoman are both investigating the assassination of an Arab leader, who opposed the sale of two French nuclear reactors to his country. The pair become convinced that the French Secret Services are involved in the assassination, and just as they are getting a little too close to the truth, an order comes from ‘the castle’ to shut down the investigation.

Credits: Producer, Jean Kerchner ; director, Serge Leroy ; writers, Yannick Flot, Serge Leroy, Francoise Giroud ; photography, Andre Domage ; music, Alain Bashung.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Nicole Garcia, Jean-Claude Brialy, Roland Blanche, Bernard Freyd.

results.title: Le Premier Age du Cinema Francais (1895-1914) Pt. 12
results.brief_description:
Part 12 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. Early French cinema was, as elsewhere, a fairground entertainment presenting novelties: short ‘realist views’ such as the Lumiere films — ‘L’arrivee d’un train en gare de La Ciotat’, ‘La sortie des usines Lumiere’, ‘Le dejeuner de bebe’ (all 1895) — comic scenes such as ‘L’arroseur arrose’ (1895) and Alice Guy’s farce ‘La fee aux choux’ (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896), inspired by contemporary cartoons and music-hall shows. It is customary to oppose the documentary impulse of the Lumieres’ cinema to the fiction of Georges Melies, who imported the tricks of his stage phantasmagorias to the screen, though the distinction appears less clear-cut. Apart from its popular success and creative, the distinctiveness of early French cinema was the business acumen of its practitioners. The Lumieres promptly took their Cinematograph to all corners of the globe, fixing for posterity the term ‘cinema’. While Melies expanded, Pathe’s and Leon Gaumont’s newly created companies were extraordinarily successful at producing, distributing (switching from selling to renting in 1907) and exhibiting their films, both at home and abroad; Pathe’s Gallic cockerel and Gaumont’s daisy became household symbols the world over, holding sway until World War I. (…) Although it did not matter much who ‘directed’, emerging personalities included, after Guy and Melies, Ferdinand Zecca, Leonce Perret, Albert Capellani and Victorin Jasset. The years preceding World War I saw the move to longer films and a rich field of detective series (‘Nick Carter’), and especially comic series: ‘Bebe’, ‘Bout-de-Zan’, ‘Calino’, ‘Onesime’, ‘Petronille’, etc …, dominated by actors Andre Deed, Max Linder and Prince.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘The companion to French cinema’. BFI Publishing, 1996. Further reading: Richard Abel. ‘French cinema: the first wave, 1915-1929’. Princeton University Press, 1984. Note: The NLA collection hold several compilations of works by Melies, Zecca, etc… as well as documentaries on women directors such as Alice Guy Blache and Germaine Dulac. N.b. Best viewed as part 1 of the series.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Includes interviews with Rene Clair, Marcel L’Herbier, Abel Gance and Roger Leenhardt.

results.title: Le Portrait de Marianne = the Picture of Marianne
results.brief_description:
Octave has just been ‘dumped’ by his wife, Marianne. Together with his good friend Alfred, they go looking for her across Paris. As their conversation unfolds, they attempts to make sense of their relationships with women.

Credits: Producer, Eric Geiger ; director, Daniel Goldenberg ; writers, Daniel Goldenberg, Edgar de Bresson ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Philippe Carson.
Cast: Claude Brasseur, Karen Blanguernon, Bernard Fresson, Liliane Rovere, Jacques Rispal.

results.title: Le Pont du Nord = North Bridge
results.creator_credit: Barbet Schroeder, Jean-Pierre Mahot and Jacques Rivette
results.brief_description:
Marie, a former terrorist, is fresh out of prison. She hopes to link up again with her former life. She contacts Julien, her former boyfriend, who does not seem too happy to see her again. When Julien mysteriously disappears, Marie goes looking for him. Here starts a surreal walk through the streets of Paris with a street map that looks like a board game and which Marie meets a dreamy homeless man, a small-time crook and destiny.

Credits: Producers, Barbet Schroeder, Jean-Pierre Mahot ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jerome Prieur, Bulle Ogier, Pascale Ogier, Jacques Rivette, Suzanne Schiffman ; photography, William Lubtchansky, Caroline Champetier ; music, Astor Piazzo
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Pascale Ogier, Pierre Clementi, Jean-Francois Stevenin, Benjamin Baltimore.

results.title: Le Plaisir = House of Pleasure
results.brief_description:
An adaptation of three ironic short stories by Guy de Maupassant ostensibly linked by a common theme: the paradoxical deceptions of pleasure. The first story, ‘Le Masque’, contrasts pleasure and old age in the story of an old man so addicted to dancing that he wears a mask to disguise his age. The second story, ‘Le Modele’, opposes pleasure and marriage. A young painter has an affair with his model, which after her attempted suicide ends with their marriage. The third, ‘La Maison Tellier’, is virtually a short feature. Pleasure and purity are opposed as the inmates of a city brothel spend a day in the country attending the first communion of the madame’s niece.

Credits: Director, Max Ophuls ; writers, Jacques Natanson ; photography, Christian Matras, Philippe Agostini ; music, Maurice Yvain, Joe Hajos ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Danielle Darrieux, Jean Gabin, Jean Servais, Claude Dauphin, Gaby Morlay, Madeleine Renaud, Helena Manson, Daniel Gelin, Simone Simon, Pierre Brasseur, Anton Wallbrook, Henri Cremieux, Paulette Dubost, Ginette Leclerc, Mila Parely, Louis Seigner

results.title: Le Pink grapefruit
results.creator_credit: Phoenix Films, Roadhouse Productions, Sue Yung Li Ikeda and Lawrence Halprin
results.brief_description: Presents a portrait of the Spanish artist Salvador Dali. Shows how his surrealism is carried over into his home and lifestyle. Includes a tour of the Salvador Dali Museum in Figeras, Spain, in which the artist discusses the building and the collection. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Le Petit Soldat = the Little Soldier
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
In Geneva, at the time of the Algerian War, a French secret agent, on a mission to kill a top man in the FLN, finds himself used as a pawn by both sides. Filmed in 1960, Godard’s second feature film was banned by the French government and released, with minor cuts, in 1963 because of its ambivalent attitude to the Algerian War and its reflection of brutality on both sides. Other reasons might have been its matter of fact filming of torture and the treatment of the political crisis as a confusing gangster movie.

Credits: Producer, Georges de beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Maurice Le Roux.
Cast: Michel Subor, Anna Karina, Henri-Jacques Huet, Laszlo Szabo, Mohamed Messoussa.

results.title: Le Petit Soldat
results.brief_description:
The peaceful life of the residents of a toy shop is disturbed by a goverment order declaring war on all toys and ordering their destruction. A mechanical acrobat, in love with a wax doll, must become a toy soldier in order to restore peace in the shop. While he is away, the wax doll falls prey to a nasty toy bird.

Credits: Producer, Andre Sarut ; director, Paul Grimault ; writers, Paul Grimault, Jacques Prevert ; music, Joseph Kosma.

results.title: Le Petit Marcel = Little Marcel
results.brief_description:
After he inherits his father’s truck, Marcel makes the big trip to Paris in the hope of setting up a transport business. While awaiting the his truck rego, he becomes involved with a gang of people under police surveillance.

Credits: Director, Jacques Fansten ; writers, Jean-Claude Grumberg, Jacques Fansten ; photography, Jean Gonnet ; music, Graeme Allwright.
Cast: Jacques Spiesser, Isabelle Huppert, Yves Robert, Jean-Francois Balmer, Michel Aumont, Anouk Ferjak ; Hubert Gignoux.
